title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 03 Introduction
section: Whatâ€™s the point in all of this?
text:
Whatâ€™s the point in all of this?
Consider the following proposition:

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 03 Introduction
text:
We have
A number of formulas that together form the proposition below. (Formula is a fancy way of saying â€˜claimâ€™)
Claim / Formula: P \(\rightarrow\) (Q & (R \(\lor\) S))

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 03 Introduction
section: This claim / formula is made up of the following claims / formulas:
text:
This claim / formula is made up of the following claims / formulas:

The claim that: â€˜Jim stole the cookieâ€™; â€˜Pâ€™
The claim that: â€˜Jim is guiltyâ€™; â€˜Qâ€™
The claim that: â€˜Jim deserves life in prisonâ€™; â€˜Râ€™
The claim that: â€˜Jim deserves deathâ€™; â€˜Sâ€™

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 03 Introduction
section: Any one of these can be true,
text:
Any one of these can be true,
Or . . . they can all be true. What we ultimately want to know, is whether together, they make a true proposition, that if:

Jim stole the cookie,

Then

Jim is guilty,

and

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 03 Introduction
text:
He either

deserves life in prison,

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 03 Introduction
section: But there are many other claims as well . . .
text:
But there are many other claims as well . . .

If Jim stole the cookie, then he is guilty.

This claim is an independent one.

Jim is guilty and deserves either life in prison, or death
He deserves life in prison or he deserves death

These are all independent claims

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 03 Introduction
section: 4 Semantic properties we can test for
text:
4 Semantic properties we can test for

Semantic Properties

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 03 Introduction
text: This is an argument

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 03 Introduction
section: Jim is guilty and deserves life in prison or death
text:
Jim is guilty and deserves life in prison or death
If Jim stole the cookie, then Jim is guilty and either he deserves life in prison or he deserves death.
Jim did steal the cookie.
Therefore, Jim is guilty and either he deserves life in prison or he deserves death.

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 03 Introduction
section: However, we are only looking at a formula, a single claim. Not an argument.
text:
However, we are only looking at a formula, a single claim. Not an argument.

An argument has a premise
And an argument has a conclusion
Ours is a single claim

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 03 Introduction
text:

text:
Letâ€™s Imagine that this is an Argument

I was supposed to be sent away But they forgot to come and get me I was a functioning alcoholic â€™Til nobody noticed my new aesthetic All of this to say I hope youâ€™re okay But youâ€™re the reason And no one hereâ€™s to blame But what about your quiet treason?


We first want to ask ourselves what is the conclusion?
There are several ways to do this. First, we attempt to recognize those sentences which most closely proximate a claim.

Then we want to order these according to premises and conclusions.
And also there are subconclusions.
These are conclusions that act as premises for more fundamental conclusions.

Logical truth, a statement true in all possible situations.
A set of propositions (or a single proposition) is inconsistent if there is no possible situation in which they are all true (or in which it is true).
Look for logical operators, terms representing logical relationships between propositions, except in the case of negations.
Some are contingent, true in some possible situations but false in others.




Words or phrases taht signal the presence of an argument.

Premise Indicators

since, because, for, as shown by, given that, may be inferred from, follows from, inasmuch as, in view of the fact that, seeing that, for the reason that, etc.

Conclusion Indicators

therefore, thus, hence, so, consequently, it follows that, we may infer that, entails that, which implies that, accordingly, as a result, etc.

title: Classical Propositional Logic
text:
Logical truth, a statement true in all possible situations.
A set of propositions (or a single proposition) is inconsistent if there is no possible situation in which they are all true (or in which it is true).
Look for logical operators, terms representing logical relationships between propositions, except in the case of negations.
Some are contingent, true in some possible situations but false in others.

title: Classical Propositional Logic
text:
Classical Propositional Logic: Syntax
In this chapter, we cover syntax, which is its grammar and rules for constructing sentences.

title: Classical Propositional Logic
text:
Argument Forms

Informal Logic: Studying arguments as they occur in natural language
Formal Logic: Argument forms

title: Classical Propositional Logic
text:
Some Valid Argument Forms


Modus Ponens
P1. P \(\rightarrow\) Q.
P2. P.
C. \(\therefore\) Q.
Modus Tollens
P1. P \(\rightarrow\) Q.
P2. ~Q.
C. \(\therefore\) ~P.

Hypothetical Syllogism
P1. P \(\rightarrow\) Q.
P2. Q \(\rightarrow\) R.
C. P \(\rightarrow\) R
Disjunctive Syllogism
P1. P \(\lor\) Q.
P2. ~P. [or ~Q.]
C. \(\therefore\) Q. [âˆ´ P.]


Constructive Dilemma
P1. P \(\lor\) Q.
P2. P \(\lor\) R.
P3. Q \(\rightarrow\) S.
C. \(\therefore\) R \(\lor\) S

title: Classical Propositional Logic
text:
Some Terms from Chapter 2
Turnstile
Sequent
Propositional Logic
Negation Operator
Disjunct
Scope Ambiguity
Automic Formulas

title: Classical Propositional Logic
text:
FORMATION RULES FOR PROPOSITIONAL LOGIC
1 Any sentence letter, with or without a sequence of numerals as a subscript, is a formula.
2 If \(\phi\) is a formula, then so is ~\(\phi\).
3 If \(\phi\) and \(\psi\) are formulas, then so are (\(\phi\) & \(\psi\)), (\(\phi\) \(\lor\) \(\psi\)), (\(\phi\) \(\rightarrow\) \(\psi\)) and (\(\phi\) \(\Leftrightarrow\) \(\psi\)).

~(P) (~P) (P): These are not formulas!


What is classical logic? What is the principle of bivalence?
DEFINITION: A valuation of a formula or set of formulas of propositional logic is an assigment of one and only one of the truth values T and F to each of the sentence letters occuring in that formula or in any formula of that set.

title: Classical Propositional Logic
text:
What are the valuation rules?



Valuation Rules

title: Classical Propositional Logic
text: Better

title: Classical Propositional Logic
text:
Some More Definitions
DEFINITION: A counterexample to a sequent or argument form is a valuation on which its premises are true and its conclusion is not true.
DEFINITION: A sequent or argument form is valid iff there is no valuation on which its premises are true and its conclusion is not true.
DEFINITION: A sequent or argument form is invalid iff there is at least one valuation on which its premises are true and its conclusion is not true.
DEFINITION: A valid formula is a formula true on all its valuations.
DEFINITION: A tautology is a formula whose truth table displays a column consisting entirely of â€™Tâ€™s under its main operator.
DEFINITION: A formula is inconsistent iff there is no valuation on which it is true.
DEFINITION: A set of formulas is inconsistent iff there is no valuation on which all the formulas in the set are true.
DEFINITION: A formula is consistent iff it is true on at least one valuation.
DEFINITION: A set of formulas is consistent iff there is at least one valuation on which all the formulas in the set are true.
DEFINITION: A formula is contingent iff it is true on some of its valuations and not true on others.
DEFINITION: Two formulas are logically equivalent iff they have the same truth value on every valuation of both.









Type of formula
Definition
Truth Table Indication




Valid (Tautologous)
True on all Valutions
Column under main operator contains only â€™Tâ€™s


Contingent
True on at least one valuation
Column under main operator contains both â€™Tâ€™s and â€™Fâ€™s


Inconsistent
True on no valuations
Column under main operator contains only â€™Fâ€™s












Type of set
Definition
Truth Table Indication





Consistent
There is at least one valuation on which all formulas in the set are true
There is at least on Horizontal line on which all formulas in the set have â€™Tâ€™s under their main operators



Inconsistent
There is no valuation on which all formulas in the set are true
There is no horizontal line on which all formulas in the set have â€™Tâ€™s under their main operators

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 08 Classical Predicate Logic
text:
Some Exercises

Beth is fortunate. So is Carl. Therefore, both Carl and Beth are fortunate.
Theft is not praiseworthy, but blameworthy. Hence theft is blameworthy.
Healing is good. So something is good.

title: Blah Stuff
text:
Informal Inferences
Which of the following arguments are valid? Where an argument is valid, sketch an informal proof.

Only medical school graduates are good doctors. No existentialists are medical school graduates. Some existentialists are French doctors. So, some French doctors are not good doctors.
Everything that happens is determined by a prior event. No action should be punished if the agent isnâ€™t responsible for it. Agents are only responsible for actions they can avoid doing. Hence no action should be punished.

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 03 Introduction
text:
Proofs

break down any valid sequent in propositional logic into a sequence of simple and (more or less) obviously valid patterns of reasoning. Such sequences, as exemplified by lines 1-8 above, are called proofs


Natural Deduction Method

Ten distinct patterns of reasoning / rules of inference / inference rules
The proof technique is Sound

If we start with true assumptions on some valuation,
we shall always, no matter how many times we apply these rules, arrive at conclusions that are likewise true on that valuation.

And complete

complete, i.e., capable of providing a proof for every valid sequent of propositional logic. ## Modus Ponens


Given \(\phi\rightarrow\psi\), and \(\phi\), infer \(\psi\)

title: Logic, Spring 2026
text:
ğŸ“‘ Introduction to Logic
 Logic, Spring 2026 
This course will begins with an informal system of logic and proceeds to classical propositional logic syntax, semantics and inference. It will then cover predicate logic semantics and inference.



â€˜Holmes wears a top hatâ€™

text:

Where: Elizabeth Hall 104

 Grey Smith  Student Peer Instructor ğŸ“§ asmith112@stetson.edu ( at )

Learning Outcomes
Through this course students will:

Learn basic logical concepts and principles of good reasoning.
Understand logical form and truth functional logic.
Learn techniques for translating sentences into logical notion and determining the validity of arguments.
Learn truth tables and other means of determining the validity of arguments stated in sentential logical notation.

What we want to know, is whether any of them acts as a logical contradiction, or fail in some other way when combined with the others. Consider the two claims below:

title: Classical Propositional Logic
section: 4 Semantic properties we can test for
text:
4 Semantic properties we can test for



Semantic Properties




Valid: The formula or sequent (argument), is true on all valuations. No counter examples (open paths)
Contingent: True on at least one, but not all valuations. (At least one open path, but not all)
Inconsistent: True on no valuations. All paths are closed.
Consistent: At least one valuation where all formulas are true. (Open paths show valuations that make the formula or set of formulas true)











Type of Formula
Definition
Truth Tree Result




Valid Sequent
There are no counter examples
No Open Paths


Invalid Sequent
There is at least one valuation where the sequent is not true
At least one open path


Valid Formula
The formula is true on all its valuations (T under main operator)
All the paths are closed


Invalid
There is at least one valuation on which the formula is False
Open paths display valuations on which formula is false














Type of Formula
Definition
Truth Tree Result




Contingent
True on at least one, but not all valuations
At least one open path, but not all


Inconsistent
Not true on any valuations
All paths are closed


Consistent
At least one valuation where all formulas are true
Open paths show valuations that make the formula or set of formulas true

title: Classical Propositional Logic
text: This is an argument

title: Classical Propositional Logic
section: Jim is guilty and deserves life in prison or death
text:
Jim is guilty and deserves life in prison or death
If Jim stole the cookie, then Jim is guilty and either he deserves life in prison or he deserves death.
Jim did steal the cookie.
Therefore, Jim is guilty and either he deserves life in prison or he deserves death.

P \(\rightarrow\) (Q & (R \(\lor\) S))
P
Therefore,
(Q & (R \(\lor\) S))

text:

Ours is a single claim

Syntax

Explain notions like

itemize
deduction, deductive validity;
logical consistency;
induction, inference to best explanation.

Introduce tests for validity, provide tools for fallacy-spotting, etc.
Familiarize you with logical symbolism â€“ i.e.Â give a â€˜reading knowledgeâ€™ of some of the languages of logic.

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 03 Introduction
ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 03 Introduction
ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 03 Introduction
ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 03 Introduction
text:
Our Terms







Term
Definition




Semantics
Study of Meaning


Truth Conditions
Conditions on which a proposition is true or false


Truth Value
T or F, A kind of semantic property that chacterizes propositions


Principle of Bivalence
Every proposition has exactly one of the two truth values, T or F


Assertibility Conditions
Conditions under which a proposition can be asserted


Interpretations
Association of sentence letters with statements of natural language


Valuation
A formula or set of formulas of propositional logic is an assignment of one and only one of the truth values T and F to each of the sentence letters occuring in that formula or any formula of that set

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 03 Introduction
section: When an argument form has more than 2 letters
text:
When an argument form has more than 2 letters

If either the peasants or the slaves revolt and the queen hesitates, then the revolution will succeed.


If the peasants revolt but the slaves donâ€™t, the revolution will not succeed, and if both the peasants and slaves revolt, the revolution will succeed.

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 03 Introduction
text:
1. Type of set: Consistent

Definition: There is at least one valuation on which all formulas in the set are true
Truth Table Indication: Horizontal line on which all formulas in the set have â€™Tâ€™s under their main operators

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 03 Introduction
text:
2. Type of set: Inconsistent

Definition: There is no valuation on which all formulas in the set are true
Truth Table Indication: There is no horizontal line on which all formulas in the set have â€™Tâ€™s under their main operators

Semantic Trees

title: Classical Propositional Logic
section: This claim / formula is made up of the following claims / formulas:
text:
This claim / formula is made up of the following claims / formulas:

The claim that: â€˜Jim stole the cookieâ€™; â€˜Pâ€™
The claim that: â€˜Jim is guiltyâ€™; â€˜Qâ€™
The claim that: â€˜Jim deserves life in prisonâ€™; â€˜Râ€™
The claim that: â€˜Jim deserves deathâ€™; â€˜Sâ€™

title: Classical Propositional Logic
section: Any one of these can be true,
text:
Any one of these can be true,
Or . . . they can all be true. What we ultimately want to know, is whether together, they make a true proposition, that if:

Jim stole the cookie,

Then

Jim is guilty,

and

title: Classical Propositional Logic
text:
He either

deserves life in prison,

title: Classical Propositional Logic
section: But there are many other claims as well . . .
text:
But there are many other claims as well . . .

If Jim stole the cookie, then he is guilty.

This claim is an independent one.

Jim is guilty and deserves either life in prison, or death
He deserves life in prison or he deserves death

These are all independent claims

What we want to know, is whether any of them acts as a logical contradiction, or fail in some other way when combined with the others. Consider the two claims below:

â€˜The boy is tallâ€™
â€˜The boy is not tallâ€™

title: Classical Propositional Logic
section: 4 Semantic properties we can test for
text:
4 Semantic properties we can test for



Semantic Properties




Valid: The formula or sequent (argument), is true on all valuations. No counter examples (open paths)
Contingent: True on at least one, but not all valuations. (At least one open path, but not all)
Inconsistent: True on no valuations. All paths are closed.
Consistent: At least one valuation where all formulas are true. (Open paths show valuations that make the formula or set of formulas true)











Type of Formula
Definition
Truth Tree Result




Valid Sequent
There are no counter examples
No Open Paths


Invalid Sequent
There is at least one valuation where the sequent is not true
At least one open path


Valid Formula
The formula is true on all its valuations (T under main operator)
All the paths are closed


Invalid
There is at least one valuation on which the formula is False
Open paths display valuations on which formula is false














Type of Formula
Definition
Truth Tree Result




Contingent
True on at least one, but not all valuations
At least one open path, but not all


Inconsistent
Not true on any valuations
All paths are closed


Consistent
At least one valuation where all formulas are true
Open paths show valuations that make the formula or set of formulas true

title: Classical Propositional Logic
text: This is an argument

title: Classical Propositional Logic
section: Jim is guilty and deserves life in prison or death
text:
Jim is guilty and deserves life in prison or death
If Jim stole the cookie, then Jim is guilty and either he deserves life in prison or he deserves death.
Jim did steal the cookie.
Therefore, Jim is guilty and either he deserves life in prison or he deserves death.

P \(\rightarrow\) (Q & (R \(\lor\) S))
P
Therefore,
(Q & (R \(\lor\) S))

title: Classical Propositional Logic
section: However, we are only looking at a formula, a single claim. Not an argument.
text:
However, we are only looking at a formula, a single claim. Not an argument.

An argument has a premise
And an argument has a conclusion
Ours is a single claim

title: Classical Propositional Logic

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 03 Introduction
text:
Semantics

Semantics is the Study of Meaning



How do you define meaning?
How does the book define meaning?


The logical meaning of an expression is usually understood as its contribution to the truth or falsity of sentences in which it occurs. [31]


Meaning is a characterization of the meaning of the use of logical operators within a given sentence.

What this correlates to, I think, is a question about how a logical operator attirbutes truth or falsehood to a sentence.
For instance, in what situations would the sentence â€œJames knows that God existsâ€ be true?
How might we imagine various sentences that confirm the truth of P?

One day, I asked James â€˜do you know who God is?â€™ He said yes and then pointed down at a rock. I then asked James â€˜does God exist?â€™ Again he pointed down at the rock and said yes, â€˜God existsâ€™.

Is the sentence â€˜James knows God existsâ€™, true in this situation?
In otherwords, the meaning of a term is its â€˜truth conditionsâ€™
What are truth conditions? The meaning of a term. Conditions on which a proposition is true or false.

The truth conditions for a term are rules which specify the possible situations in which sentences containing that term are true and the possible situations in which sentences containing that term are false.


In this section, we will give the truth-conditional semantics for the five logical operators introduced in the previous section.

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 03 Introduction
text:
Truth Conditions

The truth value of a conjunction is T in a given situation iff the truth value of each of its conjuncts is T in that situation.

and

The truth value of a conjunction is F in a given situation iff one or both of its conjuncts does not have the value T in that situation.

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 03 Introduction
section: How do the truth values of sentences containing a given logical operator depend on the truth values of their components.
text:
How do the truth values of sentences containing a given logical operator depend on the truth values of their components.

As we have seen, a valuation is a pattern of truth values.

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 03 Introduction
text:
Weâ€™ve seen this before:

The truth value of a conjunction is T \(\underline{\text{on a given valuation}}\) iff the truth value of each of its conjuncts is T in that situation.

and

The truth value of a conjunction is F \(\underline{\text{on a given valuation}}\) iff one or both of its conjuncts does not have the value T in that situation.

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 03 Introduction
text:
Valuation Rules

Because these more abstract truth conditions are stated in terms of valuations, they are often referred to as valuation rules.

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 03 Introduction
text:
As weâ€™ve seen,

\(\upsilon\) stands for valuation

and

Greek letters stand for formulas

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 03 Introduction
text:
So instead of writing,

The truth value of a conjunction is T \(\underline{\text{on a given valuation}}\) iff the truth value of each of its conjuncts is T on that valuation.


or


The truth value of a disjunction is T \(\underline{\text{on a given valuation}}\) iff the truth value of at least one of its disjuncts is T on that valuation.

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 03 Introduction
text:
Where

\(\upsilon\)(\(\phi\)) = T


and


\(\upsilon\)(\(\psi\)) = T

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 03 Introduction
text:
and
\(\upsilon\)(\(\phi\) \(\&\) \(\psi\)) = F iff \(\underline{\text{either}}\) \(\upsilon\)(\(\phi\)) = F or \(\upsilon\)(\(\psi\)) = F, or both.
or
\(\upsilon\)(\(\phi\) \(\&\) \(\psi\)) = F iff \(\underline{\text{either}}\) \(\upsilon\)(\(\phi\)) \(\neq\) T or \(\upsilon\)(\(\psi\)) \(\neq\) T, or both.


If you read the footnote, youâ€™d realize I did it the other way.

\(\upsilon\)(\(\phi\) \(\&\) \(\psi\)) = F iff \(\underline{\text{either}}\) \(\upsilon\)(\(\phi\)) \(\neq\) T or \(\upsilon\)(\(\psi\)) \(\neq\) T, or both.

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 03 Introduction
text:
Finally, Truth Tables
In tabular form, the previous rules can be expressed in the following way:



\(\phi\)
\(\psi\)
(\(\phi\)
\(\&\)
\(\psi\))




T
T

T



T
F

F



F
T

F



F
F

F

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 03 Introduction
section: Truth Conditions for the Negation Operator
text:
Truth Conditions for the Negation Operator
\(\upsilon\)(\(\neg\phi\)) = T iff \(\upsilon\)(\(\phi\)) \(\neq\) T.
\(\upsilon\)(\(\neg\phi\)) = F iff \(\upsilon\)(\(\phi\)) = T.



\(\phi\)
\(\neg\phi\)








T
F






F
T

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 03 Introduction
text:
Disjunction, â€˜Orâ€™
Inclusive

Either . . . or . . ., possibly both

Exclusive

Either . . . or . . ., not both


Four is both even and square, so
Four is either an even number or a square number, or both.
So you can mark it both wrong and right.

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 03 Introduction
section: \(\upsilon\)(\(\phi\) \(\lor\) \(\psi\)) = T iff \(\underline{\text{either}}\) \(\upsilon\)(\(\phi\)) = T or \(\upsilon\)(\(\psi\)) = T, or both.
text: \(\upsilon\)(\(\phi\) \(\lor\) \(\psi\)) = T iff \(\underline{\text{either}}\) \(\upsilon\)(\(\phi\)) = T or \(\upsilon\)(\(\psi\)) = T, or both.

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 03 Introduction
section:
\(\upsilon\)(\(\phi\) \(\lor\) \(\psi\)) \(
eq\) T iff \(\underline{	ext{either}}\) \(\upsilon\)(\(\phi\)) \(
eq\) T or \(\upsilon\)(\(\psi\)) \(
eq\) T, or both.
text:
\(\upsilon\)(\(\phi\) \(\lor\) \(\psi\)) \(
eq\) T iff \(\underline{	ext{either}}\) \(\upsilon\)(\(\phi\)) \(
eq\) T or \(\upsilon\)(\(\psi\)) \(
eq\) T, or both.

Four is both even and square, so
Four is either an even number or a square number, or both.
So you can mark it both wrong and right.
